title: Classic TV Dinners
description: How well do you remember those iconic frozen TV dinners that changed American mealtime forever?

questions.question: Which company introduced the first TV Dinner in 1953, complete with an aluminum tray designed to look like a television set?
questions.explanation: Swanson introduced the first TV Dinner in 1953, reportedly to use up a surplus of Thanksgiving turkeys. The aluminum tray was designed to resemble a TV set.

questions.question: What was the original Swanson TV Dinner meal that came in the first trays?
options: Turkey with cornbread dressing and gravy
questions.explanation: The original Swanson TV Dinner featured turkey with cornbread dressing, gravy, buttered peas, and sweet potatoes, priced at 98 cents.

questions.question: How much did the original Swanson TV Dinner cost when it debuted in 1953?
questions.explanation: The original Swanson TV Dinner sold for 98 cents when it first hit store shelves in 1953.

questions.question: What material were the original TV dinner trays made from?
questions.explanation: The iconic original TV dinner trays were made from aluminum foil, which conducted heat well in conventional ovens. They weren't replaced with plastic until the microwave era.

questions.question: Which TV dinner brand was known for its 'Hungry-Man' line of larger-portion frozen dinners, introduced in 1973?
questions.explanation: Swanson introduced the Hungry-Man line in 1973 for those who wanted bigger portions than the standard TV dinner offered.

questions.question: Which frozen dinner brand used the advertising slogan 'Nothing comes closer to home' in the 1970s and 1980s?
questions.explanation: Stouffer's used the memorable slogan 'Nothing comes closer to home' to position their frozen meals as being close to homemade quality.

questions.question: What dessert was commonly found in the small compartment of classic TV dinner trays?
questions.explanation: Apple cobbler (or apple crisp) was one of the most common desserts found in the small compartment of classic TV dinner trays.

questions.question: Which company introduced 'Lean Cuisine' frozen dinners in 1981 as a lower-calorie alternative?
questions.explanation: Stouffer's launched Lean Cuisine in 1981, capitalizing on the growing health consciousness of the era. It became one of the most successful frozen food launches ever.

questions.question: In the 1950s, what activity were TV dinners specifically designed to be eaten during?
questions.explanation: TV dinners were specifically designed and marketed to be eaten while watching television, which was the exciting new form of home entertainment in the 1950s.

questions.question: Which frozen dinner variety featured a small compartment of cranberry sauce alongside turkey?
questions.explanation: The Swanson Turkey TV Dinner famously included a small portion of cranberry sauce, making every night feel a little like Thanksgiving.

questions.question: What kitchen appliance eventually led to the redesign of TV dinner trays from aluminum to plastic?
questions.explanation: The widespread adoption of microwave ovens in the 1980s forced TV dinner manufacturers to switch from aluminum trays to microwave-safe plastic containers.

questions.question: Which budget-friendly frozen dinner brand, known for its yellow packaging, was a popular TV dinner alternative in the 1960s and 1970s?
questions.explanation: Banquet frozen dinners, with their distinctive yellow packaging, were a popular and affordable alternative to Swanson TV dinners throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

questions.question: Approximately how many Swanson TV Dinners were sold in the first full year of production (1954)?
questions.explanation: Swanson sold approximately 10 million TV Dinners in 1954, far exceeding their initial estimate of 5,000 units, proving America's appetite for convenient frozen meals.

questions.question: What was the classic Salisbury steak TV dinner typically served with?
questions.explanation: The classic Salisbury steak TV dinner almost always came with mashed potatoes smothered in brown gravy, making it one of the most beloved TV dinner varieties.

questions.question: Which company's frozen dinner line was named after a type of folding tray table commonly used while watching TV?
questions.explanation: The Swanson TV Dinner got its name from the TV tray tables that families used while eating in front of the television. The brand name itself became synonymous with any frozen dinner.
